description.narrative: Overall objective Women, girls and groups exposed to stigma and discrimination across Liberia enjoy fundamental human rights as a result of the claims of a strengthened advocacy oriented civil society and evidence of quality responses from local government and the state. Specific Objectives: Objective 1: Women, girls and particularly discriminated groups have improved access to sexual and reproductive health and rights Objective 2: Women and girls have increased protection from all forms of violence, abuse and exploitation through improved monitoring, risk assessment and prevention efforts. Objective 3: Capacity of state and non-state actors at sub-national level in 6 counties are strengthened to integrate gender and human rights in the provision of services affecting vulnerable women, youth and girls Objective 4: An inter-agency development forum developed to act with coordinated and enhanced capacity to influence gender and human rights in targeted policies and development plans at national level.

Projektet syftar till att förbättra skyddet och rättigheterna för kvinnor, flickor och andra diskriminerade grupper i sex län i Liberia. Det tar upp frågor som rör sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter, inklusive kvinnlig könsstympning och diskriminering av sexuella minoriteter som bland annat HBT personer.

The project aims to enhance the protection and rights of women, girls and other groups facing discrimination in 45 communities in four counties in Liberia. The project will address issues relating to sexual and reproductive health and rights including female genital multilation,and discrimination of sexual minorities, including respect for the human rights of LGBTI.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
Women and girls have increased access to reproductive health information and services The established forums for boys and girls in 45 communities in four counties s served as a safe spaces for young people to come together, learn, interact, and discuss issues affecting them and a platformor them to identify collective actions to address problems of concern to them. Young people increased skills and knowledge around HIV/AIDS, SRHR, and human right violations including women’s rights, gender analysis, protection laws, and referral systems at the community level. Forums members led community advocacy focusing on engaging community leaders and service providers on the provision of gender responsive services. For examples, girls’ forums in Medina, Vaye Town, Belleyala, Palala, David Dean Town, Ziah Town, Tianma Town Gbarpolu, Bong and Grand Gedeh led advocacy campaigns demanding improved SRHR and protection services in their communities. Adolescent and young women across the four counties reported easy access to safe and confidential sexual reproductive health services at local health facilities at community and sub-national levels due to increased advocacy and awareness by the forums.
Support services and networks exist to improve the sexual health and rights for stigmatized and discriminated groups The Ministry of Justice working with the Liberia National Police establisehd a Diversity Desk with assigned officers to directly support protection cases within the police departmentaffecting members of the LGBTIQ community. The Desk has contributed to significant reduction in discrimination and improvement in the handling of protection cases reported at the Police by members of the LGBTIQ community.“I am extremely happy for the project because it has brought out change and increased protection for Community members. Before the police use to arrest us even when we carry our complains. This was so frustrating for the community to the extent that a lot of community members lost their lives because of fear and discrimination. The situation has shifted a lot and we now feel safe in the community”. John Weah, member of LGBTI Community in Monrovia. Ministry of Justice also provided support with documentation, tracking, and proper follow up of such cases. As part of the process, AAL supported the development of the Universal Period Review (UPR) and Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) reporting to ensure that cases are properly documented and tracked. People living with HIV/AIDS including women across the four project counties reported improved treatment, care, and support as well. Improved measures in place to address the special needs of young women and girls engaged in sex work Increased protection for Sex Workers against SGBV: As the result of the capacity building activities (training, coaching/mentoring), sex workers actively engaged in advocacy for increase in protection against violence, stigma, and discrimination. In 2016 and 2017, sex workers in the Red-Light Community, Montserrado County held several engagement meetings with the National Police on the issue of sexual violence by police officers. Officials of the Police expressed dissatisfaction over the report of their officers not providing the required support to vulnerable groups. Strong warning was given to all officers at Zone 5 and it’s depots in the Paynesville belt. Sex workers were encouraged to continue the engagement and report any case of stigma and discrimination. To date, there has not been any report of case against police officer from these stations. Also, four engagement meetings were held with the County Health Team on the issues of access to SRHR service and psychosocial support. As the result of all these engagements, sex workers reported improvement in the handling of their cases. In 2018, with the project contribution, an Alliance (White Rose Alliance WRA) was established to continue the advocacy for the protection of sex workers specifically addressing issues affecting female sex workers. The presence of WRA has shifted the condition and position of sex workers as they are now leading advocacy at both national and sub-national levels. There are plans to decentralize the Alliance to ensure adequate protection of sex workers across the country. As a way of sustaining the gains, AAL was able to secure funding from the European Union and is currently providing economic empowerment for members of the Alliance. This will further strengthen their capacity to be able to address protection issues. Sex workers from Gbarpolu, Montserrado, and Bong are benefiting from this support. In addition, Gender Based Violence Taskforces in four counties have recognized and incorporated protection mechanisms for sex workers and other vulnerable groups. Actors in health and education at county and district level increase quality of their response to GBV and harmful traditional practice, working with CSOs and CBOs As the result of support provided to local authorities (Justice, Internal Affairs, Health, Education, and Gender ministries) there was significant improvement in the provision of services and response to SGBV and harmful traditional practices (HTPs) cases. Culture Department at Ministry of Internal Affairs (MIA) and National Council of Chiefs and Elders (NCCEL) were supported to review and document all traditional sites in the project location. The objective of this was to ensure proper documentation of licensed Zoes and their practices which ensured the regulation of activities. Over the five years, dialogue sessions were held with Ministries of Internal Affairs and Justice, NCCEL, INCHR and other stakeholders to facilitate’ improved coordination and strengthen reporting and documentation of HTP cases at both national and sub-national level. As a result, INHRC and MOJ have improved their response in handling HTP cases including documentation, referral, and follow up on cases at the court level. NATPAH in close collaboration with the FGM Working Group and other CSOs have been leading on HTPs engagement at the national and sub-national levels. The project extensively supported the drafting of the FGM Bill where several consultations were done at both national and sub-national levels. This engagement on HTP was not limited to the project locations but also across the 15 counties. In 2017, communities in Nimba reported 4 cases of rape and only 1 reach court level. Financial support was provided to the family for immediate relocation and reintegration into another community. Women in Gbarpolu and Bong championed the end to FGM; successfully leading advocacy initiatives to close 9 bush schools and ensure actions were taken against operations. Support to County Gender offices has strengthened the response to GBV cases at the community level. At national level, AAL partnered with the Liberian Feminist Forum and other CSOs to advocate for the strengthening of systems and structures to adequately address GBV issues at all levels. Over the five years period, several engagement including dialogues and protests by whom? Were held and demands presented to relevant stakeholders including UN Women and Ministry of Gender, Children and Social Protection. Advocacy campaign is still on-going and AAL will continue to collaborate with other like-minded organizations to ensure demands which were addressed.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
